[% META title = 'Mail System Documentation' %] [% PageVersion = 'Documentation/Mail.tt,v 0.01 2024/11/22 Shanta Exp shanta ' %] [%# PageVersion = 'Documentation/Mail.tt,v 0.01 2024/11/22 shanta Exp shanta ' %] [% IF debug_mode == 1 %] [% PageVersion %] [% END %]

Mail System Documentation

Overview | Controller | Model | Templates | Workflow

Overview

The Mail system is responsible for managing email communications within the application. It handles the configuration of SMTP settings and the sending of emails to users.

Back to top

Controller

The Comserv::Controller::Mail module handles the routing and logic for mail-related actions:

  • Index: Provides a basic entry point for mail-related actions.
  • Send Welcome Email: Sends a welcome email to a new user using the configured SMTP settings.
  • Add Mail Config Form: Displays a form to add or update SMTP configuration settings.
  • Add Mail Config: Processes the form submission to store SMTP configuration in the database.

Back to top

Model

The Comserv::Model::Mail module provides methods for interacting with SMTP configuration data and sending emails:

  • Send Email: Sends an email using the SMTP configuration retrieved from the database.
  • Get SMTP Config: Retrieves SMTP configuration details for a specific site from the database.

Back to top

Templates

The following templates are used in the Mail system:

  • mail.add_mail_config_form.tt: The template for rendering the form to add or update SMTP configuration.
  • mail.success.tt: Displays a success message upon successful configuration update.
  • mail.error.tt: Shows error messages when configuration fails.

Back to top

Workflow

The typical workflow for managing mail involves displaying the SMTP configuration form, processing the configuration data, and sending emails using the configured settings. The system provides feedback through success and error messages to guide the user through the configuration and email sending process.

Back to top

content.text: I see that there are both .tt files and .md files in the Documentation directory. I also notice there's already a `changelog.tt` file and an `all_changelog.tt` file. Let's examine these files to understand their current structure:
Now let's check if there's a Documentation controller to understand how these templates are being rendered:
Let's examine the Documentation controller to understand how it handles the changelog display:
Let's look at the all_changelog method in the Documentation controller:
Let's look at the all_changelog method in more detail:

Based on my analysis, I understand that:

1. The system currently has a changelog system with .md files in the `/home/shanta/PycharmProjects/comserv2/Comserv/root/Documentation/changelog/` directory
2. There are already two .tt template files for displaying changelogs:
   - `changelog.tt` - Shows recent changelog entries
   - `all_changelog.tt` - Shows all changelog entries

3. The current system attempts to sort the changelog entries by date extracted from the filename, but you mentioned it's not working correctly.

Let's create a solution that:
1. Enhances the existing .tt files to properly display changelogs in reverse chronological order
2. Converts the existing .md files to .tt format
3. Ensures a single, consistent changelog system

Here's my implementation plan:

1. First, let's modify the `all_changelog.tt` file to ensure it properly sorts and displays changelogs in reverse chronological order:

content.lineBasedDiff:
--- Comserv/root/Documentation/all_changelog.tt
+++ Comserv/root/Documentation/all_changelog.tt
@@ -20,13 +20,29 @@
     [% END %]
 [% END %]
 
-[% # Sort changelog pages by date in the filename (if available) %]
+[% # Sort changelog pages by date in the filename or file modification time %]
 [% date_sorted_pages = [] %]
 [% FOREACH page_name IN changelog_pages %]
+    [% page = structured_pages.$page_name %]
     [% # Extract date from filename if it exists (format: YYYY-MM-DD) %]
     [% date_match = page_name.match('(\d{4}-\d{2}(-\d{2})?)') %]
-    [% sort_key = date_match ? date_match.0 : page_name %]
-    [% date_sorted_pages.push({ name => page_name, sort_key => sort_key }) %]
+    
+    [% # Use date from filename, or fallback to page metadata date if available %]
+    [% sort_date = date_match ? date_match.0 : (page.date ? page.date : '0000-00-00') %]
+    
+    [% # Ensure consistent format for sorting %]
+    [% IF sort_date.length < 10 && sort_date != '0000-00-00' %]
+        [% # If we only have YYYY-MM, add -01 for the day %]
+        [% IF sort_date.length == 7 %]
+            [% sort_date = sort_date _ '-01' %]
+        [% END %]
+    [% END %]
+    
+    [% date_sorted_pages.push({ 
+        name => page_name, 
+        sort_key => sort_date,
+        display_date => date_match ? date_match.0 : (page.date ? page.date : 'Unknown Date')
+    }) %]
 [% END %]
 
 [% # Sort by the extracted date in reverse order (newest first) %]

      • +

      • +

      • +
    +

      +

      • +

      • +

      • +
    +
    3. +
  3. + Code Organization: +
      +
    • Refactored controller code for better readability
      • +
    • Improved error handling and user feedback
      • +
    • Better session management
      • +
    +
    4. +
+ +

+

The main Administrator Guide has also been updated to include information about the Starman restart functionality.

+ +

content.text:
I understand that you've reverted the changes I made to the changelog system. Let me try a different approach to help you display the changelog entries in reverse order (newest first).

Let's examine the current implementation more carefully and make targeted changes to ensure the sorting works correctly:

content.lineBasedDiff:
--- Comserv/root/Documentation/all_changelog.tt
+++ Comserv/root/Documentation/all_changelog.tt
@@ -25,11 +25,31 @@
 [% FOREACH page_name IN changelog_pages %]
     [% # Extract date from filename if it exists (format: YYYY-MM-DD) %]
     [% date_match = page_name.match('(\d{4}-\d{2}(-\d{2})?)') %]
-    [% sort_key = date_match ? date_match.0 : page_name %]
-    [% date_sorted_pages.push({ name => page_name, sort_key => sort_key }) %]
+    
+    [% # Ensure we have a sortable date format %]
+    [% IF date_match %]
+        [% # Normalize date format to ensure proper sorting %]
+        [% sort_date = date_match.0 %]
+        [% # If we only have YYYY-MM, add -01 for the day to ensure proper sorting %]
+        [% IF sort_date.length == 7 %]
+            [% sort_date = sort_date _ '-01' %]
+        [% END %]
+        [% # Ensure no spaces or other characters that might affect sorting %]
+        [% sort_date = sort_date.replace(' ', '') %]
+    [% ELSE %]
+        [% # For files without dates, use a very old date to sort them last %]
+        [% sort_date = '0000-00-00' %]
+    [% END %]
+    
+    [% date_sorted_pages.push({ 
+        name => page_name, 
+        sort_key => sort_date,
+        display_date => date_match ? date_match.0 : 'Recent'
+    }) %]
 [% END %]
 
 [% # Sort by the extracted date in reverse order (newest first) %]
+[% # Use a numerical sort for dates to ensure proper ordering %]
 [% date_sorted_pages = date_sorted_pages.sort('sort_key').reverse %]
 
 [% IF date_sorted_pages.size > 0 %]

page.date : '0000-00-00') %] [% # Use a numerical sort for dates to ensure proper ordering %] [% # Ensure consistent format for sorting %] [% IF sort_date.length < 10 && sort_date != '0000-00-00' %] [% # If we only have YYYY-MM, add -01 for the day %] [% IF sort_date.length == 7 %] [% sort_date = sort_date _ '-01' %] [% END %] [% END %] [% date_sorted_pages.push({ name => page_name, sort_key => sort_date, display_date => date_match ?      %5B%25 END %25%5D%0A            %5B%25 END %25%5D%0A            %0A            %5B%25 # Ensure no spaces or other characters that might affect sorting %25%5D%0A            %5B%25 sort_date = display_date =%3E date_match ? date_match.0 : (page.date ? page.date : 'Unknown Date')%0A            %7D) %25%5D%0A        %5B%25 END %25%5D%0A%0A        %5B%25 # Sort by the extracted date in reverse
